Biznes zyskuje na sztuce!

Nigdy wcześniej sztuka nie stanowiła tak istotnego elementu budowania strategii tożsamości marki i nigdy do tej pory nie determinowała tak dalece jej wizerunku.
Sztuka to emocje, wartości, doświadczenie. Dokładnie jak... marka.
Gucci, Fendi, Louis Vuitton, BMW, SWAROVSKI, Absolut, Bulgari.

Jak wykorzystać siłę sztuki w budowaniu marki, przeczytasz na stronach 📖: Art branding Art branding to podróż po świecie marketingu i sztuki – ujęta w formę esejów opowieść o ich wzajemnych relacjach. Książka pokazuje, jak globalne marki wprawnie otaczają się woalem wartości, które daje sztuka, i jak sztuka z mimetyczną precyzją uczy posługiwać się marketingowym instrumentarium.

Dziś w ramach cyklu #SztukaPromowania rozmawiamy z Igorem Gałązkiewiczem o art brandingu. Pytamy, po co BMW i Volkswagen  własne muzeum, co H&M po współpracy z Jeffem Koonsem. 
„Marki pragną tego anturażu i za wszelką cenę próbują się do niego dostać. Moda dała narzędzia komunikacji marketingowej – mam tu na myśli tę sezonowość, artystyczną tradycję, ten powab” PRoto - 06.02.2017 - Sztuka Promowania: Art branding, czyli Disneylandy marek „Marki pragną tego anturażu i za wszelką cenę próbują się do niego dostać. Moda dała narzędzia komunikacji marketingowej – mam tu na myśli tę sezonowość, artystyczną tradycję, ten powab” - mówi Igor Gałązkiewicz, autor książki Art branding...

BMW Art Cars have a long tradition of being amazing race cars and the newest among them, the M6 GTLM, is no exception. With a livery designed by John Baldessari, the car looked great while managing an 8th place finish at the ROLEX 24 at #Daytona this weekend. Congrats BMW! Eighth place in Daytona for the 19th BMW Art Car The 19th BMW Art Car experienced an eventful race appearance at the Daytona 24 Hours, finishing eighth in the GTLM class

Concorso d'Eleganza Villa d'Este 2015

Alongside legendary artists such as Frank Stella and Jeff Koons, BMW Art Cars have brought the world of art to a different sphere – the world of automotive. At the legendary Concorso d’Eleganza #BMW presents highlights of 40 years #BMWArtCar history live at Villa Erba.

With BMW Gesture Control in the all-new BMW 7 Series, selected functions can be operated by means of defined hand movements. Simple gestures such as 'swiping' or 'pointing' are identified in the recognition area above the centre console and trigger a variety of functions such as accepting or rejecting an incoming telephone call. Volume can be adjusted by circular motions of the index finger. BMW Gesture Control complements the existing control systems such as the iDrive Touch Controller. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos
A vision of #drivingluxury becomes reality. Line by line. Stitch by stitch. The design process of the all-new BMW 7 Series. The design process of the all-new BMW 7 Series.

The Executive Lounge rear console houses the Touch Command system. This removable 7-inch tablet computer allows the user to control the infotainment and comfort functions available in the rear of the all-new BMW 7 Series. It can also be used to play back external audio and video files, as a games console, or to surf the internet. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The all-new BMW 7 Series will be built, like all of its predecessors, at BMW Plant Dingolfing. The Dingolfing factory builds on its many years of experience in manufacturing luxury sedans. #drivingluxury Production of the all-new BMW 7 Series

The all-new BMW 7 Series is the world’s first series-produced car that owners will be able to manoeuvre in or out of forward-parking spaces or garages without anyone at the wheel. The Remote Control Parking function allows the driver to conveniently hop out of the vehicle before parking it. The driver activates the remote-controlled parking function from outside the vehicle via the BMW display key. The entire parking procedure is monitored by Park Distance Control (PDC), the Parking assistant and the Surround View sensors. In order to use the remote-controlled parking function, the vehicle has to be straight and centered, facing the parking space or garage. During the parking procedure the driver can bring the vehicle to a controlled stop if necessary. Once parked, the engine can be switched off via the key. And when it's time to move on, the engine can also be restarted via the key. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Slide up to unlock the future of #drivingluxury.
The BMW display key of the all-new BMW 7 Series shows a range of information about the vehicle's status and allows selected functions to be controlled via the integrated touch display. The time can be displayed, along with remaining fuel and current range, service notifications, as well as the current status of the central locking system, the windows and the glass roof. The BMW display key can also be used to operate Auxiliary heating and Remote Control Parking. Timeline Photos

In 1973 an entire race team drove in cars of matching design - it was the first coherent team style that the sport had seen. The three coloured stripes of blue, violet and red - set against a brilliant white background - would come to characterise the image of BMW Motorsport and continue to define the look to this day. The unbeatable BMW 3.0 CSL Coupés, kitted out in these colours, soon became known to everybody in the world of motor racing, bringing home the Touring Car Grand Prix at the Nürburgring at the very first attempt. #TriviaTuesday BMW Classic. Timeline Photos

Five BMW M4 DTM at the top: Antonio Felix da Costa celebrated his maiden DTM win. He was followed by Augusto Farfus, Bruno Spengler, Timo Glock official and Marco Wittmann. They crowned an outstanding weekend for BMW Motorsport in Zandvoort. On Saturday BMW became the first manufacturer in the history of the DTM to finish in places one to seven. Timeline Photos

BMW Motorsport made history: BMW claimed the top seven positions in the first race of the weekend in Zandvoort. Marco Wittmann won, ahead of Antonio Felix da Costa, Maxime Martin, Augusto Farfus, Bruno Spengler, Timo Glock official and Tom Blomqvist. What a victory! Timeline Photos

How to reduce weight without skimping on agility, stability, safety and comfort?

Step 1: Evaluate every part of your bodyshell and chassis,
Step 2: Fit each part with light hi-tech materials,
Step 3: Exchange existing parts for their modern counterparts.
